summary: This case involved an appeal from the High Court of the Calabar-Aba Judicial Division, where the appellant, Tita Fokum, was convicted following an order of transfer issued by a District Officer after the Native Court had already convicted and sentenced him. The West Africa Court of Appeal held that under the amended Native Courts Ordinance (No. 8 of 1938), such transfer orders could no longer be made after judgment or sentence. Since the transfer order was made on 17th October 1940—after the amendment— it was invalid. Consequently, the Court ruled that the High Court lacked jurisdiction, rendering all subsequent proceedings a nullity. The appeal was allowed, the conviction was quashed, and an order was made for the refund of the fine paid by the appellant.
verdict: Appeal allowed; conviction quashed; proceedings declared a nullity
rationaleHighlights: Order of transfer made after conviction, contrary to Ordinance No. 8 of 1938
Amendment removed authority to transfer after sentence
District Officer lacked jurisdiction to transfer post-conviction
High Court proceedings declared a nullity due to lack of valid transfer
Conviction quashed and fine ordered to be refunded
